monogr.title: A sanctuary for honest men. Or An abstract of humane wisdome : Contayning, a certaine way leading to a perfect knowledge of Man, and directing to a discreet cariage in the vvhole course of our humane condition. Collected and composed by Io: Hitchcock student in the Middle Temple
monogr.author: Hitchcock, John, student in the Middle Temple

div.head: To the READER.
div.p:
IT was not my purpose (captious or indifferent Reader) to send this little Antidote into the hungry iawes of the world which was prepared onely for my owne dyet, but the preuayling importunitie of freinds (which commonly serueth others for excuse) was to me a necessity: therfore since this dish is now come to be serued to thy Table, and so to be censur'd by thy well or ill distinguishing pallate (I meane thy rash or sounder iudgement) let me aduise thee, if thou mean'st to be nourished by it, first to ruminate
and chew it well, and afterwards to concoct it throughly before thou reiect it as an excrement; and then if any thing herein relish thee feede heartily, and welcom; but if this distaste thee, either leaue it friendly, or dish out thy owne. Carpere vel noli nostra, vel ede tua.
